justifications: Obama said the recent 'Brexit' vote in the United Kingdom to leave the European Union will not change the 'special relationship' between the two nations.
Obama said the vote on Thursday was an indication of the 'ongoing changes and challenges raised by globalization.'
Obama implied that America would be slow to sign a free trade agreement with the U.K. should it vote in favor of leaving the union.
"There might be a U.K.-U.S. trade agreement, but it's not going to happen anytime soon."
"One thing that will not change is the special relationship between our two countries, Obama said Friday, adding that the U.K.'s membership in NATO was also important."
"Obama said the vote did not impact the U.S.'s relationship with the European Union either."

Obama said the United Kingdom and the European Union will remain indispensable partners of the United States even as they begin negotiating their ongoing relationship.
